abstract.p: In this study, a survey on environmental radioactivity in 16 high schools located in north eastern region of Turkey (the black sea region, province of Trabzon) was carried out. Indoor air radon (222Rn) concentrations were measured in spring and autumn 2008 seasons using LR115 solid state nuclear track detectors and gamma radioactivity levels were measured using an HPGe gamma ray detector. It was seen that mean radon activity concentrations in schools ranged from 31 to 157 Bq/m3 for spring season and from 38 to 114 Bq/m3 for autumn season. The mean gamma activity concentrations in located areas of schools are between 18–52, 21–59, 11–97 and 265–759 Bq/kg for 226Ra, 232Th, 137Cs and 40K, respectively. The annual effective doses of students and staff received due to radon and locations’ gamma radioactivity levels are calculated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Exposure to ionizing radiation from natural sources which are cosmic rays and naturally occurring radioactive elements are a continuous and inevitable feature of life on earth. The important one of them is radon coming from the natural decay of uranium found in earth crust. Radon gas entering into the atmosphere from rocks, soil, underground water and building materials and its decay products attach to aerosols. Radon and its products inhaled with aerosols irradiate the respiratory tract and cause increasing risk of getting lung cancer [1–3]. Especially in indoor environments, exposing to ionizing radiation has greater importance due to the contributions of 40K and 238U, 232Th series and inhalation of radon gas coming from building materials, water, energy sources and geological structures underneath the built-up area [4]. Because many people spend much of their time in closed areas such as home, office, school etc., these are likely to be the most significant sources of ionizing radiation exposure. For most school children and staff, the second largest contributor to their radiation exposure is likely to be their school.

Trabzon is a coastal city straddling the Black Sea (Figure 1 [5]) and is situated on the slope of the hills. Trabzon is located in the northeastern part of Turkey between the longitudes of 38°30′–40°30′ E and the latitudes of 40°30′–41°30′ N, with a total population of 763,714 [6]. The weather is semi-cold, sub-humid with temperature variations between 3.7°C and 25°C with an average annual temperature of 14.8°C [7]. Figure 1
The sampling points of the region.

Researches on natural radioactivity in school buildings in Turkey are rather limited. Therefore, this study was carried out to determine the radioactivity level and to estimate the effective dose according to what percent of students and staff spend their time in schools in this region.

sec.title: Radon Measurement
sec.p:
In order to perform this study, 16 high schools were selected taking into account school population and the distribution of the schools in the studied region (Figure 1). Radon measurements were started in February and September 2008, each for a 4-month period. The 222Rn concentration was measured by LR-115 solid state nuclear track detectors (SSNTD) purchased from DOSIRAD, France. The detectors consist of an active layer of red cellulose nitrate on a 100 µm clear polyester-based substrate. After 4 months of exposure, the LR-115 detectors were taken out and replaced by new ones and were sent to the DOSIRAD Laboratory, France, for analysis. After the pre-etching for all the LR-115 films, the films were washed in acidified water (with HCl up to PH ≈ 3), for at least 30 min, with agitation. Then, a final rinse of 2 min at 20°C in distilled water (at least in permuted water). Before the counting process, detectors were varnished so that higher number of small tracks can be seen and counted. Finally, tracks on the film surface were counted with Kodak Eikonix CCD camera (4096 × 4096 pixels).

sec.title: Gamma Measurement in Soil
sec.p: The soil samples were collected in close vicinity of each school that the radon measurements were carried out. The surface soil samples (four soil samples in each school area) collected from the sampling sites (between 0 and 15 cm depth) were dried in an oven at a temperature of 105°C during 24 h to ensure that moisture had been completely removed and then sieved to remove the stones and pebbles, and crushed in the laboratory to produce homogenized samples. Then they were weighed, sealed and stored at least for 3 weeks to allow secular equilibrium between radium, thorium and their decay products. The gamma radiation were measured using an HPGe detector of 55% relative efficiency and resolution 1.9 keV at 1332 keV gamma of 60Co (Ortec, GEM55P4 model). Maestro 32 computer software was used for spectrum analysis. The detector was shielded with a 10 cm thick lead layer to reduce the background due to the cosmic rays and the radiation nearby the system. Full energy peak efficiency was determined using Standard Reference Material (IAEA-375) prepared by International Atomic Energy Agency. Decay corrections were performed to the sampling date. The counting time for each sample was selected to be 20,000 s to obtain the gamma spectrum with better statistics. To determine the background distribution in the environment around the detector, an empty container was counted in the same manner and in the same geometry as the samples. The background spectra were used to correct the net peak area of gamma rays of the measured isotopes.

Gamma ray transitions of energies 351.9 keV (214Pb) and 609.3 keV (214Bi) were used to determine the activity concentration of the 226Ra series. The gamma ray lines at 911.1 keV (228Ac) and 583.1 keV (208Tl) were used to determine the activity concentration of the 232Th series. The activity concentrations of 40K and 137Cs were determined directly using their 1460 keV and 661 keV gamma-ray lines, respectively.

The activity concentrations for the natural radionuclides in the measured samples were computed using Equation (1): (1)C=NɛPMt(Bq.kg-1) where N is the net counting rate of the gamma ray, ɛ is the photo peak efficiency of the detector, P is the absolute transition of gamma decay, t is the counting time in seconds and M is the weight of the dried sample in kg.

sec.title: Exposure Dose Estimation
sec.p: The annual effective dose due to radon exposure can be estimated using Equation (2) [8]: (2)AEDRn=CRn×F×O×DCF where AEDRn is the annual effective dose (mSv.y−1) due to 222Rn, CRn is radon activity concentration (Bq.m−3), F is the equilibrium factor between radon and its decay products (which is taken to be 0.4), O is the annually occupancy rate (1400 h.y−1) of 16% for students and staffs and DCF is the dose conversion factor which converts radon concentration into effective dose 9 nSv.(Bq.h.m−3)−1 [9–11].

The total absorbed dose rate in air at 1 m above ground level due to the presence of gamma rays emitted by 214Pb and 214Bi progeny of 226Ra, 232Th decay chain, 40K and 137Cs were calculated using Equation (3): (3)D=aCRa+bCTh+cCK+dCCs where a, b, c and d are the dose rates per unit activity concentrations of Ra, Th, K and Cs and CRa, CTh, CK and CCs are the activity concentrations of Ra, Th, K and Cs (Bq.kg−1), respectively. The values of a, b, c and d are taken to be 4.62 × 10−10, 6.04 × 10−10, 0.417 × 10−10 and 0.030 × 10−10 [Gy.h−1/(Bq.kg−1)], [9].

To estimate the AED, one must take into account: (a) the conversion coefficient (0.7 Sv.Gy−1) from the absorbed dose in air into effective dose and (b) the indoor occupancy factor (20%). Therefore, the effective dose rate in units of mSv.y−1 was estimated using Equation (4) [9–11]: (4)AED=D(nGy.h-1)×8760(h.y-1)×0.7 ×0.2×10-6

sec.title: Radon Measurements
sec.p:
Indoor radon concentrations (CRn) in high schools in Trabzon obtained in spring and autumn 2008 were presented in Table 2. The distribution of radon concentration according to the floors and seasons were depicted in Figure 2. As shown in Figure 2, the radon concentration measured during the spring season ranged from 11 to 277 Bq.m−3 (for ground floor), from 35 to 118 Bq.m−3 (for first floor), from 31 to 169 Bq.m−3 (for second floor) while these values ranged from 8 to 199 Bq.m−3 (for ground floor), from 28 to 105 Bq.m−3 (for first floor) and from 35 to 152 Bq.m−3 (for second floor) in autumn season. Among these studied schools, a highest radon concentration was seen in Esiroğlu Kenan Oltan High School for ground floor compared to the others. While ground floor radon concentration was 277 Bq.m−3 in Esiroğlu Kenan Oltan High School in spring, it was 199 Bq.m−3 in autumn season in that high school. Figure 2

Taking into account the action level of 200 Bq.m−3 recommended by the Turkish Atomic Energy Authority, only one of current measurement results exceeded this value. However, when EPA’s action level of 148 Bq.m−3 is considered, five values shown in Table 2 exceeded this limit. In order to reduce the indoor radon concentration in the school environment especially at ground floors, some ventilation systems should be implemented. If it is not possible, natural ventilation should be improved.

Radon concentrations are expected to decrease when moving to upper floors from ground floor as in the results of Esiroğlu Kenan Oltan High School. Percentage differences were calculated and it was found that in autumn the differences between ground floor-first floor, ground floor-second floor and first floor-second floor are 52%, 62% and 36%, respectively. The same values for spring season were found to be 47%, 51% and 40%, respectively. Also, radon concentrations were seen to be less for ground floor than upper floors in some schools. When the radon concentration results were examined, pretty lower radon concentrations were seen in the director offices in Vakfıkebir high school, Çarşıbaşı high school and Arsin high school even though the offices were located on the ground floors of the schools. When the average radon concentrations of same kind of places such as director office, conference room, staff room etc. were examined, it was seen that the average of measurements carried out in the laboratories showed highest average radon concentration for both autumn and spring. This could be attributed to a lower ventilation rate due to discontinuous usage of these laboratories. As a result, average radon levels in the laboratories were higher than the others. Indoor radon level is influenced not only by the radium content in the underlying soil and its geomorphologic properties but also many factors such as soil permeability, climatic conditions, building designs and ventilation rate [12]. Radon concentrations are seen to be less in ground floors than upper floors in some schools. From these values it can be inferred that besides soil permeability, humidity, temperature and climatic conditions, ventilation may be better for these ground floors than the upper floors in these measurement sites.

In a radon survey carried out in schools, Kosovo [13], while 74% of the rooms were below 100 Bq.m−3, about 7% and 3% of the rooms’ radon concentrations were higher than action levels proposed by the European Commission for new buildings (200 Bq.m−3) and for existing buildings (400 Bq.m−3), respectively. In another school survey done in Northern Greece, radon concentration ranged from 45 to 958 Bq.m−3 and radon concentration in 45% of the schools were higher than 200 Bq.m−3 and 12% of them were higher than 400 Bq.m−3 [14]. In this study, radon levels were lower than those reported by the other studies. In spring season, 68% of the rooms were below 100 Bq.m−3, 7% of them were higher than 148 Bq.m−3 that is action level proposed by Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and only one room showed a radon concentration higher than 200 Bq.m−3. Whereas 89% of the rooms were less than 100 Bq.m−3, 5% of them were higher than EPA action level and no room were observed to exceed 200 Bq.m−3 in autumn.

sec.title: Gamma Measurement in Soil
sec.p:
226Ra, 232Th, 137Cs and 40K gamma activities in soil samples are presented in Table 3. 226Ra, 232Th, 137Cs and 40K activities ranged from 18 to 52, 21 to 59, 11 to 97 and 265 to 759 Bq.kg−1 with the average values 35, 38, 38 and 587 Bq.kg−1, respectively. Gamma activity result of Kenan Oltan High School were seen to be almost the same compared to others, these high radon concentrations could be due to being on the ground floor and due to much discontinuous usage of laboratory compared to the classes. When obtained results were compared with other studies carried out in Kirklareli [15], in Sanliurfa [16], in Kastamonu [17] and in Adana [18] cities of Turkey, 226Ra, 40K and 232Th activities were seen to be consistent with the results, but 137Cs activity was seen to be about four times greater than the studies. On the other hand, an average 137Cs activity was measured to be 307 Bq.kg−1, which is about seven times greater than this survey in Giresun province in Black Sea region of Turkey [19]. Even though there is no record concerning this region’s 137Cs level before Chernobyl nuclear power station accident, it could be said that 137Cs activity in Trabzon was influenced by this accident. sec.title: Annual Effective Dose Due to Inhalation of Radon
sec.p:
Annual effective doses due to inhalation of 222Rn were presented for two seasons in Table 4. For Spring season, the values ranged from 0.06 to 1.4 mSv for the ground floors, for the first and the second floors annual effective doses ranged from 0.18 to 0.59 mSv and ranged from 0.16 to 0.85 mSv, respectively. For Autumn season, the values ranged from 0.15 to 1.0 mSv for the ground floors, for the first and the second floors annual effective doses ranged from 0.14 to 0.53 mSv and 0.18 to 0.77 mSv, respectively. sec.title: Annual Effective Dose Due to Inhalation Gamma Radiation from Soil
sec.p: In this study, average annual effective dose due to gamma expose naturally occurring radionuclides of 226Ra, 232Th and 40K and a manmade radionuclide of 137Cs was estimated and presented in Table 4. As shown in the table, the annual effective dose values ranged from 44 to 100 μSv for naturally occurring radionuclides. For 137Cs, the annual effective doses were estimated to change from BDL to 1.07 μSv. UNSCAER [10] reported that world annual effective doses from external expose change from 0.3 to 1.0 mSv with the average value of 0.48 mSv. The results presented in the current study are under the world average value.

In a survey carried out in Giresun province, 92 and 11 μSv average annual effective doses due to 226Ra, 232Th, 40K and 137Cs were found [19]. In another study in eastern Black Sea of Turkey, average annual effective doses were found as 93.3 and 6.15 μSv due to 226Ra, 232Th, 40K and 137Cs, respectively [20]. This study results were seen to be consistent with the data reported in literature.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This survey carried out in schools in the Black Sea Region of Turkey, Trabzon, presents information about radon activity concentrations and annual effective doses received by students and staff in the schools. In spring season, 68% of the rooms were below 100 Bq.m−3, 7% of them were higher than 148 Bq.m−3 that is action level proposed by Environmental Protection Agency, and only 1 room showed a radon concentration higher than 200 Bq.m−3. Whereas 89% of the rooms were less than 100 Bq.m−3, 5% of them were higher than EPA action level. Only one school, Esioğlu Kenan Oltan High School, exceeded the action level of 200 Bq.m−3, given by EPA and TAEK; 277 Bq.m−3 was measured in the ground floor of this school. However, no action is necessary as the average of all the floors is about 150 Bq.m−3. When radon concentrations and annual effective doses are compared to surveys carried out in different parts of the world such as Italy or Kosova, the general figure is that the current data are lower than those of the others.

As 222Rn is a daughter nucleus of 226Ra, it is expected to measure high indoor radon concentration in the schools which were built in areas containing high 226Ra activity concentrations. However, no apparent relation was found between 222Rn and 226Ra activity concentration. This was because of the fact that indoor radon concentration could be influenced by many factors such as ventilation in the building, the construction of the building, soil permeability under the building and the pressure difference between indoor and outdoor environment.

As students spend most of their time in school, it is important to estimate the dose they receive from natural radiation. UNSCEAR estimated that the world annual effective dose received by the natural radiation would change from 1 to 13 mSv with the mean value of about 2.42 mSv [10]. Indoor radon is responsible for 52% of this value which is about 1.26 mSv. External gamma doses from naturally occurring and artificial radionuclides also contribute to the dose received by the individuals. UNSCAER [10] reported that world annual effective doses from external exposure change from 0.3 to 1.0 mSv with the average value of 0.48 mSv. The current data showed lower values than the world average annual effective dose.

Students receive radiation doses generally from two sources: Dose from 222Rn in the indoor environment and dose from external exposure due to gamma rays from naturally occurring and artificial radionuclides. Current measurements showed that both indoor radon and external gamma rays could contribute to the dose received by the students under the world average values. Therefore, as a conclusion, it can be said that no action is necessary to be taken in the schools under consideration.
